headers.title: Monitoring data in Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Configuring alerts in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Alerting supports fine-grained access control. For details on mixing and matching permissions to fit your use case, see Alerting security in the OpenSearch documentation.

headers.title: Monitoring data in Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Anomaly detection in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Anomaly detection in Amazon OpenSearch Service automatically detects anomalies in your OpenSearch data in near-real time by using the Random Cut Forest (RCF) algorithm. RCF is an unsupervised machine learning algorithm that models a sketch of your incoming data stream. The algorithm computes an anomaly grade and confidence score value for each incoming data point. Anomaly detection uses these values to differentiate an anomaly from normal variations in your data.
main_header: Anomaly detection in Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Monitoring data in Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Anomaly detection in Amazon OpenSearch Service

links.title: Configuring alerts in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: You can pair the anomaly detection plugin with the Configuring alerts in Amazon OpenSearch Service plugin to notify you as soon as an anomaly is detected.
main_header: Anomaly detection in Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Monitoring data in Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Anomaly detection in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Anomaly detection is available on domains running any OpenSearch version or Elasticsearch 7.4 or later. All instance types support anomaly detection except for t2.micro and t2.small. Full documentation for anomaly detection, including detailed steps and API descriptions, is available in the OpenSearch documentation.
main_header: Anomaly detection in Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Monitoring data in Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Monitoring data in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: To get started, choose Anomaly Detection in OpenSearch Dashboards.

headers.title: Monitoring data in Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Anomaly detection in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: A detector is an individual anomaly detection task. You can create multiple detectors, and all the detectors can run simultaneously, with each analyzing data from different sources.

headers.title: Monitoring data in Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Anomaly detection in Amazon OpenSearch Service

h4.text: Step 2: Add features to your detector

text: A feature is the field in your index that you check for anomalies. A detector can discover anomalies across one or more features. You must choose one of the following aggregations for each feature: average(), sum(), count(), min(), or max().
main_header: Step 2: Add features to your detector

headers.title: Monitoring data in Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Anomaly detection in Amazon OpenSearch Service

h4.text: Step 2: Add features to your detector

text: The aggregation method determines what constitutes an anomaly. For example, if you choose min(), the detector focuses on finding anomalies based on the minimum values of your feature. If you choose average(), the detector finds anomalies based on the average values of your feature. You can add a maximum of five features per detector.
main_header: Step 2: Add features to your detector

h1.text: Anomaly detection in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: To create a monitor to send you notifications when any anomalies are detected, choose Set up alerts. The plugin redirects you to the Add monitor page where you can configure an alert.

headers.title: Monitoring data in Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Observability in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: The default installation of OpenSearch Dashboards for Amazon OpenSearch Service includes the Observability plugin, which you can use to visualize data-driven events using Piped Processing Language (PPL) in order to explore, discover, and query data stored in OpenSearch. The plugin requires OpenSearch 1.2 or later.

h1.text: Observability in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: The Observability plugin provides a unified experience for collecting and monitoring metrics, logs, and traces from common data sources. Data collection and monitoring in one place enables full-stack, end-to-end observability of your entire infrastructure. Full documentation for the Observability plugin is in the OpenSearch documentation.

h1.text: Observability in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Everyone's process for exploring data is different. If youâre new to exploring data and creating visualizations, we recommend trying a workflow like the following:

h1.text: Observability in Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: Explore your data with event analytics

main_header: Explore your data with event analytics

h1.text: Observability in Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: Explore your data with event analytics

text: To start, let's say that you're collecting flight data in your OpenSearch Service domain and you want to find out which airline had the most flights departing from Pittsburgh International Airport last month. You write the following PPL query:

It then uses the stats command to get a total count of flights and groups it according to destination airport and carrier. Finally, it uses the where clause to filter the results to flights arriving in Pittsburgh International Airport.
main_header: Explore your data with event analytics

h1.text: Observability in Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: Explore your data with event analytics

text: Here's what the data looks like when displayed over the last month:

h2.text: Explore your data with event analytics

text: You can choose the PPL button in the query editor to get usage information and examples for each PPL command:

h1.text: Observability in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: You can find more sample PPL queries under Queries and Visualizations on the Event analytics page.
main_header: Explore your data with event analytics

h1.text: Observability in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Once you correctly query the data that you're interested in, you can save those queries as visualizations:

h1.text: Observability in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Then add those visualizations to operational panels to compare different pieces of data. Leverage notebooks to combine different visualizations and code blocks that you can share with team members.

h1.text: Observability in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Trace Analytics provides a way to visualize the flow of events in your OpenSearch data to identify and fix performance problems in distributed applications.

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: You can use Trace Analytics, which is part of the OpenSearch Observability plugin, to analyze trace data from distributed applications. Trace Analytics requires OpenSearch or Elasticsearch 7.9 or later.
main_header: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: In a distributed application, a single operation, such as a user clicking a button, can trigger an extended series of events. For example, the application front end might call a backend service, which calls another service, which queries a database, which processes the query and returns a result. Then the first backend service sends a confirmation to the front end, which updates the UI.
main_header: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: You can use Trace Analytics to help you visualize this flow of events and identify performance problems.
main_header: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Trace Analytics requires you to add instrumentation to your application and generate trace data using an OpenTelemetry-supported library such as Jaeger or Zipkin. This step occurs entirely outside of OpenSearch Service. The AWS Distro for OpenTelemetry documentation contains example applications for many programming languages that can help you get started, including Java, Python, Go, and JavaScript.

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: After you add instrumentation to your application, the OpenTelemetry Collector receives data from the application and formats it into OpenTelemetry data. See the list of receivers on GitHub. AWS Distro for OpenTelemetry includes a receiver for AWS X-Ray.

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Finally, Data Prepper, an independent OpenSearch component, formats that OpenTelemetry data for use with OpenSearch. Data Prepper runs on a machine outside of the OpenSearch Service cluster, similar to Logstash.

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: For a Docker Compose file that demonstrates the end-to-end flow of data, see the OpenSearch documentation.

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: To use the OpenTelemetry Collector with Data Prepper, try the following sample configuration:

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: To send trace data to an OpenSearch Service domain, try the following sample configuration files.

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: data-prepper-config.yaml

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: pipelines.yaml

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If your domain uses fine-grained access control, you must map the Data Prepper user or role to the all_access role.

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If your domain doesn't use fine-grained access control, the Data Prepper user or role must have write permissions to several indices and templates, along with permissions to access an Index State Management (ISM) policy and retrieve cluster settings. The following policy shows the required permissions:

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Data Prepper uses port 21890 to receive data, and it must be able to connect to both the OpenTelemetry Collector and the OpenSearch cluster. For performance tuning, adjust the worker count and buffer settings in your configuration file, along with the Java virtual machine (JVM) heap size for the machine.

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Full documentation for Data Prepper is available in the OpenSearch documentation. For convenience, we also provide an AWS CloudFormation template that installs Data Prepper on an Amazon EC2 instance.

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: The Dashboard view groups traces together by HTTP method and path so that you can see the average latency, error rate, and trends associated with a particular operation. For a more focused view, try filtering by trace group name.

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: To drill down on the traces that make up a trace group, choose the number of traces in the right-hand column. Then choose an individual trace for a detailed summary.

h1.text: Trace Analytics for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: The Services view lists all services in the application, plus an interactive map that shows how the various services connect to each other. In contrast to the dashboard (which helps identify problems by operation), the service map helps you identify problems by service. Try sorting by error rate or latency to get a sense of potential problem areas of your application.

h1.text: Querying Amazon OpenSearch Service data using Piped Processing Language

text: Piped Processing Language (PPL) is a query language that lets you use pipe (|) syntax to query data stored in Amazon OpenSearch Service.
main_header: Querying Amazon OpenSearch Service data using Piped Processing Language

h1.text: Querying Amazon OpenSearch Service data using Piped Processing Language

text: The PPL syntax consists of commands delimited by a pipe character (|) where data flows from left to right through each pipeline. For example, the PPL syntax to find the number of hosts with HTTP 403 or 503 errors, aggregate them per host, and sort them in the order of impact is as follows:
main_header: Querying Amazon OpenSearch Service data using Piped Processing Language

h1.text: Querying Amazon OpenSearch Service data using Piped Processing Language

text: PPL requires either OpenSearch or Elasticsearch 7.9 or later. Detailed steps and command descriptions are available in the OpenSearch documentation.
main_header: Querying Amazon OpenSearch Service data using Piped Processing Language

h1.text: Querying Amazon OpenSearch Service data using Piped Processing Language

text: To get started, choose Query Workbench in OpenSearch Dashboards and select PPL. Use the bulk operation to index some sample data:
main_header: Querying Amazon OpenSearch Service data using Piped Processing Language

h1.text: Querying Amazon OpenSearch Service data using Piped Processing Language

text: The following example returns firstname and lastname fields for documents in an accounts index with age greater than 18:
main_header: Querying Amazon OpenSearch Service data using Piped Processing Language

h1.text: Querying Amazon OpenSearch Service data using Piped Processing Language

text: You can use a complete set of read-only commands like search, where, fields, rename, dedup, stats, sort, eval, head, top, and rare. For descriptions and examples of each command, see Commands.
main_header: Querying Amazon OpenSearch Service data using Piped Processing Language

h1.text: Querying Amazon OpenSearch Service data using Piped Processing Language

text: The PPL plugin supports all SQL functions, including mathematical, trigonometric, date-time, string, aggregate, and advanced operators and expressions. To learn more, see Functions.
main_header: Querying Amazon OpenSearch Service data using Piped Processing Language

h1.text: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: This chapter addresses some best practices for operating Amazon OpenSearch Service domains and provides general guidelines that apply to many use cases. Production domains should adhere to the following standards:
main_header: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: For more information, see the remaining topics in this chapter.
main_header: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: No surefire method of sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains exists, but by starting with an understanding of your storage needs, the service, and OpenSearch itself, you can make an educated initial estimate on your hardware needs. This estimate can serve as a useful starting point for the most critical aspect of sizing domains: testing them with representative workloads and monitoring their performance.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: Most OpenSearch workloads fall into one of two broad categories:

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: For long-lived index workloads, you can examine the source data on disk and easily determine how much storage space it consumes. If the data comes from multiple sources, just add those sources together.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: For rolling indices, you can multiply the amount of data generated during a representative time period by the retention period. For example, if you generate 200 MiB of log data per hour, that's 4.7 GiB per day, which is 66 GiB of data at any given time if you have a two-week retention period.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: The size of your source data, however, is just one aspect of your storage requirements. You also have to consider the following:

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: In summary, if you have 66 GiB of data at any given time and want one replica, your minimum storage requirement is closer to 66 * 2 * 1.1 / 0.95 / 0.8 = 191 GiB. You can generalize this calculation as follows:

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: Source Data * (1 + Number of Replicas) * (1 + Indexing Overhead) / (1 - Linux Reserved Space) / (1 - OpenSearch Service Overhead) = Minimum Storage Requirement

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: Or you can use this simplified version:

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: Source Data * (1 + Number of Replicas) * 1.45 = Minimum Storage Requirement

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

links.title: choose instance types, instance counts, and storage volumes

text: Insufficient storage space is one of the most common causes of cluster instability, so you should cross-check the numbers when you choose instance types, instance counts, and storage volumes.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: Other storage considerations exist:

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: After you understand your storage requirements, you can investigate your indexing strategy. By default in OpenSearch Service, each index is divided into five primary shards and one replica (total of 10 shards). Because you can't easily change the number of primary shards for an existing index, you should decide about shard count before indexing your first document.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: The overarching goal of choosing a number of shards is to distribute an index evenly across all data nodes in the cluster. However, these shards shouldn't be too large or too numerous. A good rule of thumb is to try to keep shard size between 10â50 GiB. Large shards can make it difficult for OpenSearch to recover from failure, but because each shard uses some amount of CPU and memory, having too many small shards can cause performance issues and out of memory errors. In other words, shards should be small enough that the underlying OpenSearch Service instance can handle them, but not so small that they place needless strain on the hardware.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: For example, suppose you have 66 GiB of data. You don't expect that number to increase over time, and you want to keep your shards around 30 GiB each. Your number of shards therefore should be approximately 66 * 1.1 / 30 = 3. You can generalize this calculation as follows:

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: (Source Data + Room to Grow) * (1 + Indexing Overhead) / Desired Shard Size = Approximate Number of Primary Shards

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: This equation helps compensate for data growth over time. If you expect those same 66 GiB of data to quadruple over the next year, the approximate number of shards is (66 + 198) * 1.1 / 30 = 10. Remember, though, you don't have those extra 198 GiB of data yet. Check to make sure that this preparation for the future doesn't create unnecessarily tiny shards that consume huge amounts of CPU and memory in the present. In this case, 66 * 1.1 / 10 shards = 7.26 GiB per shard, which will consume extra resources and is below the recommended size range. You might consider the more middle-of-the-road approach of six shards, which leaves you with 12 GiB shards today and 48 GiB shards in the future. Then again, you might prefer to start with three shards and reindex your data when the shards exceed 50 GiB.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: A far less common issue involves limiting the number of shards per node. If you size your shards appropriately, you typically run out of disk space long before encountering this limit. For example, an m6g.large.search instance has a maximum disk size of 512 GiB. If you stay below 80% disk usage and size your shards at 20 GiB, it can accommodate approximately 20 shards. OpenSearch 7.x and later have a limit of 1,000 shards per node. To adjust the maximum shards per node, configure the cluster.max_shards_per_node setting. See an example here.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: Sizing shards appropriately almost always keeps you below this limit, but you can also consider the number of shards for each GiB of Java heap. On a given node, have no more than 20 shards per GiB of Java heap. For example, an m5.large.search instance has a 4 GiB heap, so each node should have no more than 80 shards. At that shard count, each shard is roughly 5 GiB in size, which is well below our recommendation.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: After you calculate your storage requirements and choose the number of shards that you need, you can start to make hardware decisions. Hardware requirements vary dramatically by workload, but we can still offer some basic recommendations.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: In general, the storage limits for each instance type map to the amount of CPU and memory that you might need for light workloads. For example, an m6g.large.search instance has a maximum EBS volume size of 512 GiB, 2 vCPU cores, and 8 GiB of memory. If your cluster has many shards, performs taxing aggregations, updates documents frequently, or processes a large number of queries, those resources might be insufficient for your needs. If you believe your cluster falls into one of these categories, try starting with a configuration closer to 2 vCPU cores and 8 GiB of memory for every 100 GiB of your storage requirement.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: Still, even those resources might be insufficient. Some OpenSearch users report that they need many times those resources to fulfill their requirements. Finding the right hardware for your workload means making an educated initial estimate, testing with representative workloads, adjusting, and testing again:

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: To start, we recommend a minimum of three nodes to avoid potential OpenSearch issues, such as split brain (when a lapse in communication leads to a cluster having two master nodes). If you have three dedicated master nodes, we still recommend a minimum of two data nodes for replication.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

h3.text: Step 2: Calculate storage requirements per node

text: If you have a 184 GiB storage requirement and the recommended minimum number of three nodes, use the equation 184 / 3 = 61 GiB to find the amount of storage that each node needs. In this example, you might select three m6g.large.search instances, each using a 90 GiB EBS storage volume so that you have a safety net and some room for growth over time. This configuration provides 6 vCPU cores and 24 GiB of memory, so it's suited to lighter workloads.
main_header: Step 2: Calculate storage requirements per node

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

h3.text: Step 2: Calculate storage requirements per node

text: For a more substantial example, consider a 14 TiB (14,336 GiB) storage requirement and a heavy workload. In this case, you might choose to begin testing with 2 * 144 = 288 vCPU cores and 8 * 144 = 1152 GiB of memory. These numbers work out to approximately 18 i3.4xlarge.search instances. If you don't need the fast, local storage, you could also test 18 r6g.4xlarge.search instances, each using a 1 TiB EBS storage volume.
main_header: Step 2: Calculate storage requirements per node

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

h3.text: Step 2: Calculate storage requirements per node

links.title: Petabyte scale for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If your cluster includes hundreds of terabytes of data, see Petabyte scale for Amazon OpenSearch Service.
main_header: Step 2: Calculate storage requirements per node

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: After configuring the cluster, you can add your indices using the number of shards you calculated earlier, perform some representative client testing using a realistic dataset, and monitor CloudWatch metrics to see how the cluster handles the workload.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: If performance satisfies your needs, tests succeed, and CloudWatch metrics are normal, the cluster is ready to use. Remember to set CloudWatch alarms to detect unhealthy resource usage.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: If performance isn't acceptable, tests fail, or CPUUtilization or JVMMemoryPressure are high, you might need to choose a different instance type (or add instances) and continue testing. As you add instances, OpenSearch automatically rebalances the distribution of shards throughout the cluster.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: Because it is easier to measure the excess capacity in an overpowered cluster than the deficit in an underpowered one, we recommend starting with a larger cluster than you think you need. Next, test and scale down to an efficient cluster that has the extra resources to ensure stable operations during periods of increased activity.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: Production clusters or clusters with complex states benefit from dedicated master nodes, which improve performance and cluster reliability.

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Petabyte scale for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Amazon OpenSearch Service domains offer attached storage of up to 3 PB. You can configure a domain with 200 i3.16xlarge.search instance types, each with 15 TB of storage. Because of the sheer difference in scale, recommendations for domains of this size differ from our general recommendations. This section discusses considerations for creating domains, costs, storage, and shard size.
main_header: Petabyte scale for Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Petabyte scale for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: While this section frequently references the i3.16xlarge.search instance types, you can use several other instance types to reach 1 PB of total domain storage.
main_header: Petabyte scale for Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Dedicated master nodes in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Amazon OpenSearch Service uses dedicated master nodes to increase cluster stability. A dedicated master node performs cluster management tasks, but does not hold data or respond to data upload requests. This offloading of cluster management tasks increases the stability of your domain. Just like all other node types, you pay an hourly rate for each dedicated master node.
main_header: Dedicated master nodes in Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Dedicated master nodes in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: We recommend that you add three dedicated master nodes to each production OpenSearch Service domain. Never choose an even number of dedicated master nodes. Consider the following when choosing the number of dedicated master nodes:
main_header: Dedicated master nodes in Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Dedicated master nodes in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If a cluster has an even number of master-eligible nodes, OpenSearch and Elasticsearch versions 7.x and later ignore one node so that the voting configuration is always an odd number. In this case, four dedicated master nodes are essentially equivalent to three (and two to one).
main_header: Dedicated master nodes in Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Dedicated master nodes in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Dedicated master nodes perform the following cluster management tasks:
main_header: Dedicated master nodes in Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Dedicated master nodes in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: The following illustration shows an OpenSearch Service domain with ten instances. Seven of the instances are data nodes and three are dedicated master nodes. Only one of the dedicated master nodes is active; the two gray dedicated master nodes wait as backup in case the active dedicated master node fails. All data upload requests are served by the seven data nodes, and all cluster management tasks are offloaded to the active dedicated master node.
main_header: Dedicated master nodes in Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Dedicated master nodes in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Although dedicated master nodes don't process search and query requests, their size is highly correlated with the number of instances, indices, and shards that they can manage. For production clusters, we recommend the following instance types for dedicated master nodes. These recommendations are based on typical workloads and can vary based on your needs. Clusters with many shards or field mappings can benefit from larger instance types. Monitor the dedicated master node metrics to see if you need to use a larger instance type.
main_header: Dedicated master nodes in Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Recommended CloudWatch alarms for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: CloudWatch alarms perform an action when a CloudWatch metric exceeds a specified value for some amount of time. For example, you might want AWS to email you if your cluster health status is red for longer than one minute. This section includes some recommended alarms for Amazon OpenSearch Service and how to respond to them.
main_header: Recommended CloudWatch alarms for Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Recommended CloudWatch alarms for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: You can automatically deploy these alarms using AWS CloudFormation. For a sample stack, see this GitHub repository.
main_header: Recommended CloudWatch alarms for Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Recommended CloudWatch alarms for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: For more information about configuring alarms, see Creating Amazon CloudWatch Alarms in the Amazon CloudWatch User Guide.
main_header: Recommended CloudWatch alarms for Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Best practices for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Recommended CloudWatch alarms for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Consider configuring the following alarms depending on which OpenSearch Service features you regularly use.

h1.text: Features by engine version

text: Many OpenSearch Service features have a minimum OpenSearch version requirement or legacy Elasticsearch OSS version requirement. If you meet the minimum version for a feature, but the feature isn't available on your domain, update your domain's service software.

headers.title: General reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Features by engine version

text: For information about plugins, which enable some of these features and additional functionality, see Plugins by engine version. For information about the OpenSearch API for each version, see Supported operations.

headers.title: General reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Plugins by engine version

text: Amazon OpenSearch Service domains come prepackaged with plugins from the OpenSearch community. The service automatically deploys and manages plugins for you, but it deploys different plugins depending on the version of OpenSearch or legacy Elasticsearch OSS you choose for your domain.

headers.title: General reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Plugins by engine version

text: The following table lists plugins by OpenSearch version, as well as compatible versions of legacy Elasticsearch OSS. It only includes plugins that you might interact withâitâs not comprehensive. OpenSearch Service uses additional plugins to enable core service functionality, such as the S3 Repository plugin for snapshots and the OpenSearch Performance Analyzer plugin for optimization and monitoring. For a complete list of all plugins running on your domain, make the following request:

headers.title: General reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Supported operations

text: OpenSearch Service supports many versions of OpenSearch and legacy Elasticsearch OSS. The following sections show the operations that OpenSearch Service supports for each version.

headers.title: General reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Supported operations

text: OpenSearch Service only accepts PUT requests to the _cluster/settings API that use the "flat" settings form. It rejects requests that use the expanded settings form.

headers.title: General reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Supported operations

text: The high-level Java REST client uses the expanded form, so if you need to send settings requests, use the low-level client.

headers.title: General reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Supported operations

text: Prior to Elasticsearch 5.3, the _cluster/settings API on OpenSearch Service domains supported only the HTTP PUT method, not the GET method. OpenSearch and later versions of Elasticsearch support the GET method, as shown in the following example:

headers.title: General reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Supported operations

text: Here is a return example:

headers.title: General reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Supported operations

text: If you compare responses from an open source OpenSearch cluster and OpenSearch Service for certain settings and statistics APIs, you might notice missing fields. OpenSearch Service redacts certain information that exposes service internals, such as the file system data path from _nodes/stats or the operating system name and version from _nodes.

headers.title: General reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Supported operations

text: The _shrink API can cause upgrades, configuration changes, and domain deletions to fail. We don't recommend using it on domains that run Elasticsearch versions 5.3 or 5.1. These versions have a bug that can cause snapshot restoration of shrunken indices to fail.

h1.text: Reserved Instances in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Reserved Instances (RIs) in Amazon OpenSearch Service offer significant discounts compared to standard On-Demand Instances. The instances themselves are identical; RIs are just a billing discount applied to On-Demand Instances in your account. For long-lived applications with predictable usage, RIs can provide considerable savings over time.
main_header: Reserved Instances in Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: General reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Reserved Instances in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: OpenSearch Service RIs require one- or three-year terms and have three payment options that affect the discount rate:
main_header: Reserved Instances in Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: General reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Reserved Instances in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Generally speaking, a larger upfront payment means a larger discount. You can't cancel Reserved Instancesâwhen you reserve them, you commit to paying for the entire termâand upfront payments are nonrefundable.
main_header: Reserved Instances in Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: General reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Reserved Instances in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: RIs are not flexible; they only apply to the exact instance type that you reserve. For example, a reservation for eight c5.2xlarge.search instances does not apply to sixteen c5.xlarge.search instances or four c5.4xlarge.search instances. For full details, see Amazon OpenSearch Service pricing and FAQ.
main_header: Reserved Instances in Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: General reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Reserved Instances in Amazon OpenSearch Service

links.title: Analyzing Your Costs with Cost Explorer

text:
Cost Explorer is a free tool that you can use to view your spending data for the past 13 months. Analyzing this data helps you identify trends and understand if RIs fit your use case. If you already have RIs, you can group by
Purchase Option and show amortized costs to compare that spending to your spending for On-Demand Instances. You can also set usage budgets to make sure you are taking full advantage of your reservations. For more information, see Analyzing Your Costs with Cost Explorer in the AWS Billing User Guide.

h1.text: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

text: This chapter includes several start-to-finish tutorials for working with Amazon OpenSearch Service, including how to migrate to the service, build a simple search application, and create a visualization in OpenSearch Dashboards.

h1.text: Migrating to Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Index snapshots are a popular way to migrate from a self-managed OpenSearch cluster to Amazon OpenSearch Service. Broadly, the process consists of the following steps:

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Migrating to Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: This walkthrough provides more detailed steps and alternate options, where applicable.

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Migrating to Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Although you can use the repository-s3 plugin to take snapshots directly to S3, you have to install the plugin on every node, tweak opensearch.yml, restart each node, add your AWS credentials, and finally take the snapshot. The plugin is a great option for ongoing use or for migrating larger clusters.

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Migrating to Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: For smaller clusters, a one-time approach is to take a shared file system snapshot and then use the AWS CLI to upload it to S3. If you already have a snapshot, skip to step 4.

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Migrating to Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Although the console is the easiest way to create a domain, in this case, you already have the terminal open and the AWS CLI installed. Modify the following command to create a domain that fits your needs:

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Migrating to Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: As is, the command creates an internet-accessible domain with two data nodes, each with 100 GiB of storage. It also enables fine-grained access control with HTTP basic authentication and all encryption settings. Use the OpenSearch Service console if you need a more advanced security configuration, such as a VPC.

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Migrating to Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Before issuing the command, change the domain name, master user credentials, and account number. Specify the same AWS Region that you used for the S3 bucket and an OpenSearch/Elasticsearch version that is compatible with your snapshot.

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Migrating to Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: Provide permissions to the S3 bucket

text: In the AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) console, create a role with the following permissions and trust relationship. When creating the role, choose S3 as the AWS Service. Name the role OpenSearchSnapshotRole so it's easy to find.
main_header: Provide permissions to the S3 bucket

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h2.text: Provide permissions to the S3 bucket

main_header: Provide permissions to the S3 bucket

h2.text: Provide permissions to the S3 bucket

text: Trust relationship

h1.text: Migrating to Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: Provide permissions to the S3 bucket

text: Then give your personal IAM user or roleâwhatever you used to configure the AWS CLI earlierâpermissions to assume OpenSearchSnapshotRole. Create the following policy and attach it to your identity:
main_header: Provide permissions to the S3 bucket

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h2.text: Provide permissions to the S3 bucket

h1.text: Migrating to Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: Provide permissions to the S3 bucket

h3.text: Map the snapshot role in OpenSearch Dashboards (if using fine-grained access control)

text: If you enabled fine-grained access control, even if you use HTTP basic authentication for all other purposes, you need to map the manage_snapshots role to your IAM user or role so you can work with snapshots.
main_header: Map the snapshot role in OpenSearch Dashboards (if using fine-grained access control)

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Migrating to Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: At this point, you have two ways to access your OpenSearch Service domain: HTTP basic authentication with your master user credentials or AWS authentication using your IAM credentials. Because snapshots use Amazon S3, which has no concept of the master user, you must use your IAM credentials to register the snapshot repository with your OpenSearch Service domain.

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Migrating to Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Most programming languages have libraries to assist with signing requests, but the simpler approach is to use a tool like Postman and put your IAM credentials into the Authorization section.

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Migrating to Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: At this point, the migration is complete. You might configure your clients to use the new OpenSearch Service endpoint, resize the domain to suit your workload, check the shard count for your indices, switch to an IAM master user, or start building visualizations in OpenSearch Dashboards.

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Creating a search application with Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: A common way to create a search application with Amazon OpenSearch Service is to use web forms to send user queries to a server. Then you can authorize the server to call the OpenSearch APIs directly and have the server send requests to OpenSearch Service.
main_header: Creating a search application with Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Creating a search application with Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If you want to write client-side code that doesn't rely on a server, however, you should compensate for the security and performance risks. Allowing unsigned, public access to the OpenSearch APIs is inadvisable. Users might access unsecured endpoints or impact cluster performance through overly broad queries (or too many queries).
main_header: Creating a search application with Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Creating a search application with Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: This chapter presents a solution: use Amazon API Gateway to restrict users to a subset of the OpenSearch APIs and AWS Lambda to sign requests from API Gateway to OpenSearch Service.
main_header: Creating a search application with Amazon OpenSearch Service

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Creating a search application with Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: A prerequisite for this tutorial is an OpenSearch Service domain. If you don't already have one, follow the steps in Create an OpenSearch Service domain to create one.

text: Download sample-movies.zip, unzip it, and use the _bulk API to add the 5,000 documents to the movies index:

For more information about creating Lambda functions and deployment packages, see Deploy Python Lambda functions with .zip file archives in the AWS Lambda Developer Guide and Create the Lambda deployment package in this guide.

text: The handler is the method in your function code that processes events. You need to change the handler name according to the name of the file in your deployment package where the Lambda function is located. For example, if your file is named function.py, rename the handler to function.lambda_handler. For more information, see Lambda function handler in Python.

h1.text: Visualizing customer support calls with OpenSearch Service and OpenSearch Dashboards

text: This chapter is a full walkthrough of the following situation: a business receives some number of customer support calls and wants to analyze them. What is the subject of each call? How many were positive? How many were negative? How can managers search or review the the transcripts of these calls?
main_header: Visualizing customer support calls with OpenSearch Service and OpenSearch Dashboards

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Visualizing customer support calls with OpenSearch Service and OpenSearch Dashboards

text: A manual workflow might involve employees listening to recordings, noting the subject of each call, and deciding whether or not the customer interaction was positive.
main_header: Visualizing customer support calls with OpenSearch Service and OpenSearch Dashboards

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Visualizing customer support calls with OpenSearch Service and OpenSearch Dashboards

text: Such a process would be extremely labor-intensive. Assuming an average time of 10 minutes per call, each employee could listen to only 48 calls per day. Barring human bias, the data they generate would be highly accurate, but the amount of data would be minimal: just the subject of the call and a boolean for whether or not the customer was satisfied. Anything more involved, such as a full transcript, would take a huge amount of time.
main_header: Visualizing customer support calls with OpenSearch Service and OpenSearch Dashboards

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Visualizing customer support calls with OpenSearch Service and OpenSearch Dashboards

text: Using Amazon S3, Amazon Transcribe, Amazon Comprehend, and Amazon OpenSearch Service, you can automate a similar process with very little code and end up with much more data. For example, you can get a full transcript of the call, keywords from the transcript, and an overall "sentiment" of the call (positive, negative, neutral, or mixed). Then you can use OpenSearch and OpenSearch Dashboards to search and visualize the data.
main_header: Visualizing customer support calls with OpenSearch Service and OpenSearch Dashboards

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Visualizing customer support calls with OpenSearch Service and OpenSearch Dashboards

text: While you can use this walkthrough as-is, the intent is to spark ideas about how to enrich your JSON documents before you index them in OpenSearch Service.

headers.title: Amazon OpenSearch Service tutorials

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: This topic describes how to identify and solve common Amazon OpenSearch Service issues. Consult the information in this section before contacting AWS Support.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: The OpenSearch Dashboards endpoint doesn't support signed requests. If the access control policy for your domain only grants access to certain IAM users or roles and you haven't configured Amazon Cognito authentication, you might receive the following error when you attempt to access Dashboards:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

links.title: About access policies on VPC domains
Identity and Access Management in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If your OpenSearch Service domain uses VPC access, you might not receive this error, but the request might time out. To learn more about correcting this issue and the various configuration options available to you, see Controlling access to OpenSearch Dashboards, About access policies on VPC domains, and Identity and Access Management in Amazon OpenSearch Service.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

links.title: About access policies on VPC domains

text: See About access policies on VPC domains and Testing VPC domains.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Compared to earlier Elasticsearch versions, OpenSearch and Elasticsearch 7.x use a different system for cluster coordination. In this new system, when the cluster loses quorum, the cluster is unavailable until you take action. Loss of quorum can take two forms:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If quorum loss occurs and your cluster has more than one node, OpenSearch Service restores quorum and places the cluster into a read-only state. You have two options:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If you prefer to use the cluster as-is, verify that cluster health is green using the following request:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If cluster health is red, we recommend restoring the cluster from a snapshot. You can also see Red cluster status for troubleshooting steps. If cluster health is green, check that all expected indexes are present using the following request:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Then run some searches to verify that the expected data is present. If it is, you can remove the read-only state using the following request:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If quorum loss occurs and your cluster has only one node, OpenSearch Service replaces the node and does not place the cluster into a read-only state. Otherwise, your options are the same: use the cluster as-is or restore from a snapshot.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: In both situations, OpenSearch Service sends two events to your AWS Health Dashboard. The first informs you of the loss of quorum. The second occurs after OpenSearch Service successfully restores quorum. For more information about using the AWS Health Dashboard, see the AWS Health User Guide.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: A red cluster status means that at least one primary shard and its replicas are not allocated to a node. OpenSearch Service keeps trying to take automated snapshots of all indexes regardless of their status, but the snapshots fail while the red cluster status persists.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: The most common causes of a red cluster status are failed cluster nodes and the OpenSearch process crashing due to a continuous heavy processing load.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Ultimately, red shards cause red clusters, and red indexes cause red shards. To identify the indexes causing the red cluster status, OpenSearch has some helpful APIs.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Deleting red indexes is the fastest way to fix a red cluster status. Depending on the reason for the red cluster status, you might then scale your OpenSearch Service domain to use larger instance types, more instances, or more EBS-based storage and try to recreate the problematic indexes.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If deleting a problematic index isn't feasible, you can restore a snapshot, delete documents from the index, change the index settings, reduce the number of replicas, or delete other indexes to free up disk space. The important step is to resolve the red cluster status before reconfiguring your OpenSearch Service domain. Reconfiguring a domain with a red cluster status can compound the problem and lead to the domain being stuck in a configuration state of Processing until you resolve the status.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If your cluster's status is continuously red for more than an hour, OpenSearch Service attempts to automatically fix it by rerouting unallocated shards or restoring from past snapshots.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If it fails to fix one or more red indexes and the cluster status remains red for a total of 14 days, OpenSearch Service takes further action only if the cluster meets at least one of the following criteria:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: At this time, if your cluster meets one of these criteria, OpenSearch Service sends you daily notifications over the next 7 days explaining that if you don't fix these indexes, all unassigned shards will be deleted. If your cluster status is still red after 21 days, OpenSearch Service deletes the unassigned shards (storage and compute) on all red indexes. You receive notifications in the Notifications panel of the OpenSearch Service console for each of these events. For more information, see Cluster health events.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

h3.text: Recovering from a continuous heavy processing load

text: To determine if a red cluster status is due to a continuous heavy processing load on a data node, monitor the following cluster metrics.
main_header: Recovering from a continuous heavy processing load

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: A yellow cluster status means the primary shards for all indexes are allocated to nodes in a cluster, but the replica shards for at least one index aren't. Single-node clusters always initialize with a yellow cluster status because there's no other node to which OpenSearch Service can assign a replica. To achieve green cluster status, increase your node count. For more information, see Sizing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Multi-node clusters might briefly have a yellow cluster status after creating a new index or after a node failure. This status self-resolves as OpenSearch replicates data across the cluster. Lack of disk space can also cause yellow cluster status; the cluster can only distribute replica shards if nodes have the disk space to accommodate them.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: You might receive a ClusterBlockException error for the following reasons.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If one or more nodes in your cluster has less than 20% of available storage space, or less than 20 GB of storage space, basic write operations like adding documents and creating indexes can start to fail. Calculating storage requirements provides a summary of how OpenSearch Service uses disk space.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: To avoid issues, monitor the FreeStorageSpace metric in the OpenSearch Service console and create CloudWatch alarms to trigger when FreeStorageSpace drops below a certain threshold. GET /_cat/allocation?v also provides a useful summary of shard allocation and disk usage. To resolve issues associated with a lack of storage space, scale your OpenSearch Service domain to use larger instance types, more instances, or more EBS-based storage.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

h3.text: Blocked disks due to low memory

text: When the JVMMemoryPressure metric exceeds 92% for 30 minutes, OpenSearch Service triggers a protection mechanism and blocks all write operations to prevent the cluster from reaching red status. When the protection is on, write operations fail with a ClusterBlockException error, new indexes can't be created, and the IndexCreateBlockException error is thrown.
main_header: Blocked disks due to low memory

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

h3.text: Blocked disks due to low memory

text: When the JVMMemoryPressure metric returns to 88% or lower for five minutes, the protection is disabled, and write operations to the cluster are unblocked.
main_header: Blocked disks due to low memory

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: A JVM OutOfMemoryError typically means that one of the following JVM circuit breakers was reached.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Amazon EC2 instances might experience unexpected terminations and restarts. Typically, OpenSearch Service restarts the nodes for you. However, it's possible for one or more nodes in an OpenSearch cluster to remain in a failed condition.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: To check for this condition, open your domain dashboard on the OpenSearch Service console. Go to the Cluster health tab and find the Total nodes metric. See if the reported number of nodes is fewer than the number that you configured for your cluster. If the metric shows that one or more nodes is down for more than one day, contact AWS Support.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: You can also set a CloudWatch alarm to notify you when this issue occurs.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: To protect your clusters from unexpected node terminations and restarts, create at least one replica for each index in your OpenSearch Service domain.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: OpenSearch as well as 7.x versions of Elasticsearch have a default setting of no more than 1,000 shards per node. OpenSearch/Elasticsearch throw an error if a request, such as creating a new index, would cause you to exceed this limit. If you encounter this error, you have several options:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Your OpenSearch Service domain enters the "Processing" state when it's in the middle of a configuration change. When you initiate a configuration change, the domain status changes to "Processing" while OpenSearch Service creates a new environment. In the new environment, OpenSearch Service launches a new set of applicable nodes (such as data, master, or UltraWarm). After the migration completes, the older nodes are terminated.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: The cluster can get stuck in the "Processing" state if either of these situations occurs:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

links.title: Why is my Amazon OpenSearch Service domain stuck in the "Processing" state?

text: For detailed resolution steps in each of these situations, see Why is my Amazon OpenSearch Service domain stuck in the "Processing" state?.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: You might encounter the following error when you try to enable audit log publishing using the OpenSearch Service console:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: The Resource Access Policy specified for the CloudWatch Logs log group does not grant sufficient permissions for Amazon OpenSearch Service to create a log stream. Please check the Resource Access Policy.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If you encounter this error, verify that the resource element of your policy includes the correct log group ARN. If it does, take the following steps:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If the error persists after repeating the process several times, contact AWS Support.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: OpenSearch Service supports the _close API only for OpenSearch and Elasticsearch versions 7.4 and later. If you're using an older version and are restoring an index from a snapshot, you can delete the existing index (before or after reindexing it). The other option is to use the rename_pattern and rename_replacement fields to rename the index as you restore it:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If you plan to reindex, shrink, or split an index, you likely want to stop writing to it before performing the operation.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Elasticsearch 7.10 deprecated the following parameters for use within dynamic templates: coerce, dynamic, ignore_malformed, normalizer, null_values, omit_norms, and properties.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If you add a document to an index with a dynamic template that contains a deprecated parameter, you get the following error:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If you encounter this error, remove the deprecated parameter from your template and retry the request.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: The default distributions of Logstash and Beats include a proprietary license check and fail to connect to the open source version of OpenSearch. Make sure you use the Apache 2.0 (OSS) distributions of these clients with OpenSearch Service.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If you receive persistent 403 Request throttled due to too many requests or 429 Too Many Requests errors, consider scaling vertically. Amazon OpenSearch Service throttles requests if the payload would cause memory usage to exceed the maximum size of the Java heap.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

links.title: Configuration API reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: You can't use SSH to access any of the nodes in your OpenSearch cluster, and you can't directly modify opensearch.yml. Instead, use the console, AWS CLI, or SDKs to configure your domain. You can specify a few cluster-level settings using the OpenSearch REST APIs, as well. To learn more, see Configuration API reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service and Supported operations.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

links.title: publish error logs and slow logs to CloudWatch

text: If you need more insight into the performance of the cluster, you can publish error logs and slow logs to CloudWatch.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: "Not Valid for the Object's Storage Class" snapshot error

text: OpenSearch Service snapshots do not support the S3 Glacier storage class. You might encounter this error when you attempt to list snapshots if your S3 bucket includes a lifecycle rule that transitions objects to the S3 Glacier storage class.
main_header: "Not Valid for the Object's Storage Class" snapshot error

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: "Not Valid for the Object's Storage Class" snapshot error

text: If you need to restore a snapshot from the bucket, restore the objects from S3 Glacier, copy the objects to a new bucket, and register the new bucket as a snapshot repository.
main_header: "Not Valid for the Object's Storage Class" snapshot error

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: OpenSearch Service requires that clients specify Host in the request headers. A valid Host value is the domain endpoint without https://, such as:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: If you receive an Invalid Host Header error when making a request, check that your client or proxy includes the OpenSearch Service domain endpoint (and not, for example, its IP address) in the Host header.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: OpenSearch Service doesn't support adding or modifying M3 instances to existing domains running OpenSearch or Elasticsearch versions 6.7 and later. You can continue to use M3 instances with Elasticsearch 6.5 and earlier.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: We recommend choosing a newer instance type. For domains running OpenSearch or Elasticsearch 6.7 or later, the following restriction apply:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: Hot queries stop working after enabling UltraWarm

text: When you enable UltraWarm on a domain, if there are no preexisting overrides to the search.max_buckets setting, OpenSearch Service automatically sets the value to 10000 to prevent memory-heavy queries from saturating warm nodes. If your hot queries are using more than 10,000 buckets, they might stop working when you enable UltraWarm.
main_header: Hot queries stop working after enabling UltraWarm

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: Hot queries stop working after enabling UltraWarm

text: Because you can't modify this setting due to the managed nature of Amazon OpenSearch Service, you need to open a support case to increase the limit. Limit increases don't require a premium support subscription.
main_header: Hot queries stop working after enabling UltraWarm

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: In-place upgrades are irreversible, but if you contact AWS Support, they can help you restore the automatic, pre-upgrade snapshot on a new domain. For example, if you upgrade a domain from Elasticsearch 5.6 to 6.4, AWS Support can help you restore the pre-upgrade snapshot on a new Elasticsearch 5.6 domain. If you took a manual snapshot of the original domain, you can perform that step yourself.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: Need summary of domains for all AWS Regions

text: The following script uses the Amazon EC2 describe-regions AWS CLI command to create a list of all Regions in which OpenSearch Service could be available. Then it calls list-domain-names for each Region:
main_header: Need summary of domains for all AWS Regions

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: Need summary of domains for all AWS Regions

text: You receive the following output for each Region:
main_header: Need summary of domains for all AWS Regions

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: Need summary of domains for all AWS Regions

text: Regions in which OpenSearch Service is not available return "Could not connect to the endpoint URL."
main_header: Need summary of domains for all AWS Regions

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: Browser error when using OpenSearch Dashboards

text: Your browser wraps service error messages in HTTP response objects when you use Dashboards to view data in your OpenSearch Service domain. You can use developer tools commonly available in web browsers, such as Developer Mode in Chrome, to view the underlying service errors and assist your debugging efforts.
main_header: Browser error when using OpenSearch Dashboards

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: Unauthorized operation after selecting VPC access

text: When you create a new domain using the OpenSearch Service console, you have the option to select VPC or public access. If you select VPC access, OpenSearch Service queries for VPC information and fails if you don't have the proper permissions:
main_header: Unauthorized operation after selecting VPC access

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: Unauthorized operation after selecting VPC access

text: To enable this query, you must have access to the ec2:DescribeVpcs, ec2:DescribeSubnets, and ec2:DescribeSecurityGroups operations. This requirement is only for the console. If you use the AWS CLI to create and configure a domain with a VPC endpoint, you don't need access to those operations.
main_header: Unauthorized operation after selecting VPC access

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: Stuck at loading after creating VPC domain

text: After creating a new domain that uses VPC access, the domain's Configuration state might never progress beyond Loading. If this issue occurs, you likely have AWS Security Token Service (AWS STS) disabled for your Region.
main_header: Stuck at loading after creating VPC domain

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

h2.text: Stuck at loading after creating VPC domain

text: To add VPC endpoints to your VPC, OpenSearch Service needs to assume the AWSServiceRoleForAmazonOpenSearchService role. Thus, AWS STS must be enabled to create new domains that use VPC access in a given Region. To learn more about enabling and disabling AWS STS, see the IAM User Guide.
main_header: Stuck at loading after creating VPC domain

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Alpine Linux limits DNS response size to 512 bytes. If you try to connect to your OpenSearch Service domain from Alpine Linux, DNS resolution can fail if the domain is in a VPC and has more than 20 nodes. If your domain is in a VPC, we recommend using other Linux distributions, such as Debian, Ubuntu, CentOS, Red Hat Enterprise Linux, or Amazon Linux 2, to connect to it.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Because AWS SDKs use the CA certificates from your computer, changes to the certificates on the AWS servers can cause connection failures when you attempt to use an SDK. Error messages vary, but typically contain the following text:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: You can prevent these failures by keeping your computer's CA certificates and operating system up-to-date. If you encounter this issue in a corporate environment and do not manage your own computer, you might need to ask an administrator to assist with the update process.

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: The following list shows minimum operating system and Java versions:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: The three certificate authorities are:

h1.text: Troubleshooting Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: Root certificates from the first two authorities are available from Amazon Trust Services, but keeping your computer up-to-date is the more straightforward solution. To learn more about ACM-provided certificates, see AWS Certificate Manager FAQs.

h1.text: Configuration API reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

links.title: Creating and managing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains

text: This reference describes the actions, data types, and errors in the Amazon OpenSearch Service configuration API. The configuration API is a REST API that you can use to create and configure OpenSearch Service domains over HTTP. You also can use the AWS CLI and the console to configure OpenSearch Service domains. For more information, see Creating and managing Amazon OpenSearch Service domains.
main_header: Configuration API reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

links.title: Enabling encryption of data at rest

text: Specifies whether the domain should encrypt data at rest, and if so, the AWS Key Management Service (KMS) key to use. Can be used only to create a new domain, not update an existing one. To learn more, see Enabling encryption of data at rest.

h1.text: Configuration API reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

h1.text: Configuration API reference for Amazon OpenSearch Service

links.title: Setting OpenSearch logging thresholds for slow logs

text: Specifies whether the OpenSearch Service domain publishes the OpenSearch application and slow logs to Amazon CloudWatch. You still have to enable the collection of slow logs using the OpenSearch REST API. To learn more, see Setting OpenSearch logging thresholds for slow logs.

Document history for Amazon OpenSearch Service and Amazon Elasticsearch
			Service

links.title: Service software updates in Amazon OpenSearch Service

text: This topic describes important changes to Amazon OpenSearch Service and its predecesor, Amazon Elasticsearch Service. Service software updates add support for new features, security patches, bug fixes, and other improvements. To use new features, you might need to update the service software on your domain. For more information, see Service software updates in Amazon OpenSearch Service.
